ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Reading, writing, speaking, and listening skills

I learned so much Chinese, specifically substantiating the proper grammar for things I had some experiential knowledge about from speaking Chinese at home. The most valuable thing I learned was how to read and write in Chinese.
I learned to speak elementary Chinese. I learned how to write and read.
I learned how to write, read, speak, and listen to many Chinese characters (around 400). My grammar greatly improved and could speak to family with improved sentence structure.

I learned proper Chinese grammar for the first time, which allowed me to be able to better communicate without having to switch to English mid sentence, and I was able to expand my Chinese vocabulary as well as writing. I think the biggest strength is this course is the community it provided me to be able to confidently express myself in Chinese to peers outside of my family and improve my Chinese speaking skills.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: No weaknesses, Chan Laoshi was amazing!

Strengths: Chan Laoshi is amazing, so kind, and patient; the class is structured to be super engaging, it's impossible to not be paying attention for all of class
Weaknesses: Some of the Padlet assignments could be characterized as busy work, honestly not many weaknesses other than that

Strengths: I thought this course taught me so much Chinese, especially coming in as a heritage speaker. I never learned to read or write at home, and taking this course allowed me to do so. You will also learn pinyin which is a very vital skill.
Strengths were that the class was engaging and never felt slow or boring. The class covers a lot of material but it is structured well to make the process enjoying.
I improved a lot in my Chinese both verbally and in writing and reading. It is well-paced and keeps learning Chinese fun.
Strength: I enjoyed the format, where Fridays were turned into virtual exploration days, where students could collaborate for group projects and explore Chinese culture on their own.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, absolutely! If you are looking to improve your Chinese, this is the fastest way to do it.
Would recommend if you have the time, very worth your while. Very high engagement course, be prepared to sink a lot of your time into it. Chan laoshi is amazing!!
Yes! Absolutely! Take this if you're an illiterate heritage speaker like I was!

I would recommend this course if you are truly interested in writing Chinese characters and if you have the time in your schedule. This course truly makes you dedicate a chunk of your time per day to learn. There are daily quizzes which requires you to study every night. You must learn a new lesson every two days which requires you to be on top of your other classes. The class is very fast paced. If you don't have this time, I recommend you take the non-heritage track.
Yes absolutelythe earlier the better and during a semester where you can make it a 1st or 2nd priority.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! The professors are extremely caring, and each class is engaging and entertaining. I had a difficult time expressing myself when I first entered the class, but now I can engage in full conversations with my parents and send texts in Chinese.
